title: The Tower of Babel and Genealogy of Shem
shortSummary: Genesis 11 recounts the story of humanity's attempt to build a city and a tower reaching heaven, leading God to confuse their language and scatter them across the earth. The chapter also provides the genealogy of Shem, tracing the lineage from Noah to Abram, setting the stage for God's covenant promises.
timeline: Post-Flood period, traditionally dated around c. 2300-2100 BC

keyCharacters.name: Abram
keyCharacters.description: Son of Terah, later called Abraham; a key patriarch whose lineage begins in this chapter.

keyCharacters.name: Terah
keyCharacters.description: Father of Abram, Nahor, and Haran; led his family from Ur to Haran.

keyCharacters.name: Haran
keyCharacters.description: Son of Terah and father of Lot; died in Ur before his father.

keyCharacters.name: Lot
keyCharacters.description: Son of Haran; nephew of Abram, mentioned as part of Terah’s household.

definitions.definition: The name of the city where God confused the language of humanity, causing them to scatter; associated with the Hebrew word for 'confuse.'
In this context, a sticky substance used as mortar in brick-making, likely bitumen or tar.
A binding substance used to hold bricks together in construction.
A term used in genealogies to denote the lineage or descendants of a particular person.

outline.heading: The Unified Language and the Tower of Babel
outline.description: Humanity, speaking one language, settles in Shinar and decides to build a city with a tower reaching heaven to make a name for themselves and avoid being scattered.

outline.heading: God’s Intervention and the Confusion of Languages
outline.description: God observes their pride and unity, confounds their language to prevent their plans, and scatters them over the earth, ending the construction of the city called Babel.

outline.heading: Genealogy of Shem from Noah to Terah
outline.description: The chapter traces the descendants of Shem, listing ages and offspring, culminating in Terah, the father of Abram.

outline.heading: Terah’s Family and Migration
outline.description: Terah’s family is introduced, including Abram, Nahor, Haran, and Lot; Terah leads them from Ur toward Canaan but dies in Haran.

application: Trust in God's sovereignty over human plans and ambitions, recognizing that pride and self-reliance apart from God lead to confusion and division.
Value unity under God’s purpose rather than human efforts to make a name for ourselves apart from Him.
Remember the importance of obedience to God’s calling, as seen in Abram’s family journeying toward the Promised Land.
Recognize the faithfulness of God in preserving His covenant line through Shem’s descendants despite human failures.

keyVerses.text: And the LORD said, Behold, the people is one, and they have all one language; and this they begin to do: and now nothing will be restrained from them, which they have imagined to do.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the potential of unified humanity and the reason God intervened to limit their prideful ambitions.

keyVerses.text: Therefore is the name of it called Babel; because the LORD did there confound the language of all the earth: and from thence did the LORD scatter them abroad upon the face of all the earth.
keyVerses.significance: It explains the origin of diverse languages and the scattering of people, showing God's direct involvement in human history.

keyVerses.text: And Terah lived seventy years, and begat Abram, Nahor, and Haran.
keyVerses.significance: This verse introduces the key patriarch Abram, through whom God’s covenant promises will unfold.
